title.narrative: THET District Hospital HTM Improvement Project

description.narrative:
Tropical Health and Educational Trust (THET) har sökt Sida-finansiering av för 2018-2021 för att utföra "Health Technology Management in District Hospitals" i Eastern, Southern, Luapula och Muchinga-provinserna i Zambia. I samma provinser genomför hälsovårdsministeriet programmet Reproductive Maternal Newborn Child Adolescent Health & Nutrition (RMNCAHN) med finansiering från Sida och USAID under perioden 2016-2020.
Det övergripande målet med det föreslagna projektet är att stödja utvecklingen av en förbättrad infrastruktur i utvalda distriktssjukhus för professionell ledning och hantering av teknisk hälsovårdsutrustning. Detta kommer att se till att utrustningen är väl underhållen och tillgänglig för bästa vård. På så sätt optimeras fördelarna med finansiella investeringar i utrustning. De viktigaste målen är: • Placering av formellt utbildade biomedicinska ingenjörstekniker (BMET) på distriktsnivå vid sjukhus i provinserna Southern, Eastern, Muchinga och Luapula för att påskynda reparationer, arbeta med förebyggande underhåll och utbilda användare, vilket resulterar i förbättrad körtid av medicinsk utrustning. • Förbättring av verkstadsutrymme och verktyg, inklusive tillhandahållande av verktygslådor, testutrustning och IT-verktyg för att göra det möjligt för ingenjörsteknikerna att genomföra underhåll. • Utförande av ett utbildningsprogram för deltagande BMET som består av en teknisk och en ledarskapsinriktning. Detta kommer att säkerställa att rutiner och vägledning kring användandet av utrustningen implementeras av BMET på sjukhusen. • Ökad datainsamling och analys av effekterna på utrustningens körtid och andra mätvärden. • Tillhandahållande av en fond för upphandling av reservdelar. Detta kommer att användas för att underhålla utrustningen på ett kostnadseffektivt sätt. • En rigorös utvärdering av projektet för att informera givare och nyckelaktörer om programmets effektivitet och bidra till den växande evidensbasen kring positiva effekter av välutbildade ingenjörstekniker.

Tropical Health and Educational Trust (THET) has applied to Sida for funding to Carry out the " District Hospital Health Technology Management Improvement Project in District Hospitals" in Eastern, Southern, Luapula and Muchinga provinces of Zambia concurrently running the Ministry of Health Reproductive Maternal Newborn Child Adolescent Health& Nutrition (RMNCAHN) programme during the period 2018-2021. The overall goal of the proposed project is to support the development of an improved infrastructure in selected health care facilities for professional health care technology management. This will ensure that equipment is well maintained and available for patient use. In this way, benefits of financial investments in equipment are optimized. The key objectives are: • Placement of formally trained BiomedicalEngineering Technologists ( BMETs) in district level hospitals in Southern, Eastern,Muchinga and Luapula Provinces to increase the timeliness of repairs, instigate preventative maintenance and provide user training; resulting in improved up time (useful running time) of medical equipment. These provinces are conducting the MOH RMNCAHN continuum of care programme. • The improvement of workshop space and utilities, including the provision of tool-boxes,test equipment, and IT tools to enable BMETs to undertake maintenance activities. • Successful delivery of an in service training program for participating BMETs consisting of a technical and a management mentoring. This will ensure that well defined standard operating procedures are implemented by BMETs in the facilities. • Increased data collection and analysis recording the impact of the maintenance activities on equipment up-time and other metrics. • Provision of a procurement fund for spare-parts. This will be used to maintain equipment in a cost effective and efficient manner. • Rigorous evaluation of the project to inform donors and key stakeholders of impact and contribute to the growing evidence base around the positive impact of appropriately trained BMETs on the ability to provide health services to the community.

description.narrative: THET has continued with the project despite initial challenges posed by the Covid 19 pandemic which limited support and field activities by the project office. However the BMETs who are located in the selected district hospitals continued with their work although they faced initial challenges of protective clothing and equipment. They appealed to Sida and were allowed to make provisions to ensure their staff and patients safety. Sida also shared with them the communication from the Sida DG to all partners of Sida on the Covid 19 pandemic and Sida's support. During the second project year, 30 qualified Biomedical Engineering Technologists (BMETs) were placed in 30 different level 1 and 2 hospitals, of these 13 were a cohort from the first year of implementation and 17 a second cohort joining the programme for the first time. They received the following support to carry out professional medical equipment maintenance: the provision of a hospital workshop, technical and IT tools, a mentorship program with a spare parts budget and an e-learning course on Standards Operation Procedures (SOPs) for BMETs. For the second cohort of BMETs, this placement was their first work experience and served as an internship. All BMETs on this project implement the same activities which include maintaining an inventory of medical equipment, performing corrective and preventive maintenance, providing technical training for clinical users, performing commissioning and decommissioning of equipment, establishing priorities for new equipment procurement and reporting on the status of the medical equipment to management. The first cohort of BMETs, who had previously participated in the first year of the project, continued to work according to the SOPs and received additional project assignments, including the fulfilment of a medical equipment Outreach programme, to establish and improve the medical equipment status in 86 (38 Easteran, 10 Luapula, 7 Muchinga and 31 Southern) rural health centres in their respective districts. The key performance indicator used to measure the success of the project is the uptime of medical equipment in the participating facilities. By the end of the second year, the second cohort of BMETs had increased the medical equipment uptime in their hospitals from a baseline of 73% to 97% at the end of their placement. The first cohort of BMETs maintained the medical equipment uptime above 95% throughout the project year, also ending the project at with an average of 97%. The second year of the project saw the introduction of a medical equipment outreach’ programme by the first cohort of BMETs. to maintain the medical equipment in health centres within their Districts. The BMET outreach trips were limited to single day activities.The standard equipment list for health centres in Zambia requires the presence of (at least) 31 medical devices, including: water distillers, autoclaves, blood pressure machines, examination lights, stethoscopes, weighing scales, suction pumps, thermometers, binocular microscopes, glucometers and haemoglobinometers. However, the average number of medical equipment units in the health centres covered was only 16 units; only nine of the health centres visited had more than 25 units.In total 157 health centre visits were executed by the 13 BMETs. Some of the BMETs were held back by the lack of available transport facilities in their hospital/district. This became more of challenge with the advent of Covid 19 which restricted movement by the health authorities. Budget spending resulted in an underspending of US$118,013 for the year. This was to a number of activities being postponed, amended reduced or cancelled due to restrictions put for the Covid-19 pandemic. The other main impact was from the depreciation of the Zambian Kwacha versus the US$, which caused many local costs, such as salaries, to be lower than budgeted, when expressed in US$. The project support officer for THET, Misheck Kasaro, was caught in a corruption scandal involving ZMW 30 593.20 and this was reported to Sida. The said employee was dismissed and is facing charges in the criminal courts of law.On 1st April 2020, Eunice Sinyemu, THET’s Country Director, received a confidential letter from the Financial Intelligence Centre (FIC) requesting that THET Zambia avail details of payments made to Misheck’s account at the first national bank (FNB Zambia). They explained that they had identified unusual behaviour in his account and that they needed the details as part of their inquiry into his financial affairs. THET were informed that they would credit Sida with the stolen funds which they did, as they recovered the funds from the former employees terminal benefits. The Controller Karin Sahlén and Sida investigations were involved and reports were submitted as required. The terms of reference for the audit due were adjusted to ensure that all transactions were audited. THET will submit a final report once the investigations by the state agency are completed.
